facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 4 of 1952 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 4 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 134 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th May, 1951,

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Allahabad delivered Judgment and Order dated 7th May 1951 in Criminal Appeal No. 350 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 7th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Criminal Appeal No. 350 of 1950

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Etah delivered Judgment and Order dated 9th March 1950 in Sessions Trials Nos. 127 of 1949 and 10 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 9th March, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Etah in Sessions Trials Nos. 127 of 1949 and 10 of 1950.

facts.text: Twenty-four persons, including the two appellants, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-Twenty-four persons, among them the two appellants, were tried for offences under sections 148, 307/149 and 302/149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sixteen persons were acquitted at trial.

anchor.surface_text: Sixteen were acquitted and the remainmg eight were companyvicted.

facts.text: Eight persons were convicted at trial.

anchor.surface_text: Sixteen were acquitted and the remainmg eight were companyvicted.

facts.text: High Court acquitted five more persons on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court five more were acquitted and the only ones whose companyvictions were upheld

facts.text: High Court upheld convictions of Nar Singh, Roshan Singh, and Nanhu Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court five more were acquitted and the only ones whose companyvictions were upheld were the two appellants, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh, and one Nanhu Singh.

facts.text: High Court misread evidence and mixed up Nanhu Singh with Bechan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: By a curious misreading of the evidence this Nanhu Singh was mixed up with Bechan Singh. What the High Court really meant to do was to companyvict Bechan Singh

facts.text: High Court acquitted Bechan Singh and convicted Nanhu Singh by mistake.

anchor.surface_text: What the High Court really meant to do was to companyvict Bechan Singh and acquit Nanhu Singh. Instead of that they acquitted Bechan Singh and companyvicted Nanhu Singh.

facts.text: High Court Judges communicated mistake to State Government.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the learned High Court Judges realised their mistake they companymunicated with the State Government

facts.text: State Government remitted sentence of Nanhu Singh and directed his release.

anchor.surface_text: and an order was thereupon passed by that Government remitting the sentence mistakenly Passed on Nanhu and directing that he be released.

facts.text: Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh applied for certificate under Article 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: This occasioned an application under article 134 1   c  of the Constitution by Nanhu Singh and the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh for a certificate.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate to Nanhu Singh, Nar Singh and Roshan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly companysidered that the certificate should issue in the case of Nanhu Singh because, despite the remission of his sentence by the State Government and his release,

facts.text: Nanhu Singh's conviction for murder still stood despite remission and release.

anchor.surface_text: his companyviction on, among other things, a charge of murder still stood, and the High Court, understandably, thought that the stigma of that might affect him adversely in the future.

facts.text: Only Nar Singh and Roshan Singh appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Having obtained the certificate Nanhu did number appeal and the only ones who have companye up here are the two companyvicts.

facts.text: A number of persons joined in an attack at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.

anchor.surface_text: A number of persons joined in an attack at two in the morning on helpless persons who were asleep in bed.

facts.text: High Court found there were more than five persons involved.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants.

facts.text: Eye-witnesses identified the two appellants Nar Singh and Roshan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 5, 1954 by BOSE J.

facts.text: Supreme Court treats the case as one under Article 136(1) for special leave.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

facts.text: Use of Section 149 IPC was justified.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does number weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified

issues.text: Does the term 'case' in Article 134(1)(c) refer to the entire appeal as a whole or to the case of each individual person?

anchor.surface_text: that they were bound to do so because article 134 1   c  speaks of a case and they companysidered that the only CC case before them was the appeal as a whole. That, in our opinion, is wrong. Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a companymon memorandum of appeal  if the Rules of the Court in question so permit , the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

issues.text: Upon obtaining a certificate under Article 134(1)(c), does the Supreme Court become an ordinary Court of appeal bound to hear the case on facts and law?

anchor.surface_text: But, it was companymended on their behalf that having obtained a certificate we have number become an ordinary Court of appeal and are bound to hear their case as an appellate Court both on facts and on law. Reliance was placed on a decision of the Federal Court reported in Subhanand Chowdhary v. Apurba Krishna Mitra 1 . We do number think the judgment of the Federal Court can be applied to this case.

issues.text: Did the High Court properly exercise its judicial discretion in granting the certificate under Article 134(1)(c)?

anchor.surface_text: Article 134 1   c  uses the same language as article 133 1   c . A certificate is, required under article 133 1 . in each of the four cases set out there but the mere grant of the certificate would number preclude this Court from determining whether it was rightly granted and whether the companyditions prerequisite to the grant are satisfied. In the case of clause  c  both of article 133 1  and article 134 1 , the only companydition is the discretion of the High Court but the discretion is a judicial one and must be judicially exercised along the well established lines which govern these matters  see Banarsi Parshad v. Kashi Krishna  2  also the certificate must show on the face of it that the discretion companyferred was invoked and exercised Radhakrishna Ayyar v. Swaminatha Ayyar  3  and Radha Krishn Das v. Rai Krishn Chand  4 .

issues.text: Is there a proper case for grant of special leave to appeal under Article 136?

anchor.surface_text: Having obtained the certificate Nanhu did number appeal and the only ones who have companye up here are the two companyvicts. Had they companye up independently and presented a petition for special leave under article 136 their petition would at once have been dismissed because there is numberhing special in their cases to justify an appeal under that article.

issues.text: Were more than five persons involved in the offence justifying the application of Section 149 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave. Regarded from that angle, this is number a proper case for special leave. The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does number weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the companyvictions are proper.

anchor.surface_text: that they were bound to do so because article 134 1   c  speaks of a case and they considered that the only CC case before them was the appeal as a whole.

arguments.claim: The term 'case' in Article 134(1)(c) means the case of each individual person, not the appeal as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: That, in our opinion, is wrong. Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a common memorandum of appeal if the Rules of the Court in question so permit, the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

arguments.claim: Having obtained a certificate under Article 134(1)(c), the Supreme Court becomes an ordinary Court of appeal bound to hear the case both on facts and on law.

arguments.claim: Supreme Court has power to determine if certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was rightly granted as discretion of High Court is judicial and must be exercised along well-established lines.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has general powers of judicial superintendence over all Courts in India and is the ultimate interpreter and guardian of the Constitution. It has a duty to see that its provisions are faithfully observed and, where necessary, to expound them. Article 134 1   c  uses the same language as article 133 1   c .

arguments.claim: High Court misdirected itself by thinking no option to grant certificate and fettered its discretion.
Certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was wrongly granted to the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

arguments.claim: No proper case for special leave under Article 136 as nothing special and evidence against appellants clear.

anchor.surface_text: Had they come up independently and presented a petition for special leave under article 136 their petition would at once have been dismissed because there is nothing special in their cases to justify an appeal under that article. The evidence against them is clear and it has been believed,

arguments.claim: More than five persons involved justifying Section 149 IPC and convictions proper.

holdings.text: Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a common memorandum of appeal if the Rules of the Court in question so permit, the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

anchor.surface_text: That, in our opinion, is wrong. Case as used there means the case of each individual person. That would be so even if the trial had been by the High Court itself but it is even more so on appeal because, though several persons may join in presenting a companymon memorandum of appeal  if the Rules of the Court in question so permit , the appeal of each forms a separate case for those purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation: even on joint appeal, each person's case is separate; otherwise acquitted persons would need inclusion.

holdings.text: We do not think the judgment of the Federal Court can be applied to this case. It deals with section 205 of the Government of India Act, 1935, conferring a different subject and does not use the same or similar words.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think the judgment of the Federal Court can be applied to this case. It deals with section 205 of the Government of India Act, 1935, companyering a different subject and does number use the same or similar words.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent: Federal Court case under different provision with different words.

holdings.text: This Court has general powers of judicial superintendence over all Courts in India and is the ultimate interpreter and guardian of the Constitution. [...] the discretion is a judicial one and must be judicially exercised along the well established lines which govern these matters [citing precedents].

anchor.surface_text: This Court has general powers of judicial superintendence over all Courts in India and is the ultimate interpreter and guardian of the Constitution. It has a duty to see that its provisions are faithfully observed and, where necessary, to expound them. Article 134 1   c  uses the same language as article 133 1   c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court's superintendence power allows review of judicial discretion exercised along established lines; cites precedents on judicial discretion.

holdings.text: In the present case, the learned High Court Judges thought they had no option. They misdirected themselves about the law and as a consequence did not exercise the discretion which is vested in them.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the learned High Court Judges thought they had numberoption. They misdirected themselves about the law and as a companysequence did number exercise the discretion which is vested in them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court fettered discretion by misunderstanding 'case' as whole appeal, not exercising per law.

holdings.text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the certificate was wrongly granted to the appellants and will treat their case as one under article 136 1  for special leave.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate invalid due to misdirection; convert to Art 136 petition.

holdings.text: Had they come up independently and presented a petition for special leave under article 136 their petition would at once have been dismissed because there is nothing special in their cases to justify an appeal under that article. anchor.surface_text: Having obtained the certificate Nanhu did number appeal and the only ones who have companye up here are the two companyvicts. Had they companye up independently and presented a petition for special leave under article 136 their petition would at once have been dismissed because there is numberhing special in their cases to justify an appeal under that article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No special circumstances; clear evidence believed by High Court.

holdings.text: The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye-witnesses who identify the two appellants. The mere fact that only two out of the band of attackers were satisfactorily identified does not weaken the force of the finding that more than five were involved. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the convictions are proper. We see no reason to interfere with the sentences.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court gives a clear finding that there were more than five persons and believes the eye- witnesses who identify the two appellants. The use of section 149, Indian Penal Code, was therefore justified and the companyvictions are proper.
